instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
Hi, this mac had liquid damage and came with oxidation on the USB-C controllers on one side (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>). I did a cleaning but it was not successful. When I made measurements in reverse diode mode on the LDO signals, on all four controllers, I got:

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>:         0.466V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>:            0.517V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>:   0.495V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>:          0.501V

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>:         0.469V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>:            0.517V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>:   0.499V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>:          0.503V

UB400
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>:         0.465V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>:           0.517V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>:  0.495V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>:         0.502V

UB300
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>:          0.471V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>:            0.517V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>:   0.504V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>:          0.509V


Next, I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> (because they were oxidized too much initially) and also UB300, for presenting slightly altered values compared to the other chips. 
The board turns on and the system goes up, but as initially, it does not show any activity in any of the four ports, and the keyboard does not work (probably because of the liquid, although I have not tested another). I can't get past the user login screen, because I can't type the password (because of the keyboard) and I can't use an external keyboard, because none of the four ports work. Sometimes, even on this screen, the machine restarts by itself and apparently generates an error report, but I can't see it because it is not possible to access the system.

Can you help me with what measurements I should take? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
So actually machine powers up with all four USB-C ports, but none of them has USB activity?
Do you get 5V at corresponding coil, L3500, or LB700?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
No, the machine will not power up when plugging the charger into any of the ports. I could only turn it on because the battery still has charge. L3500 and LB700 both have 0V (even connected to the charger)
 When I plug in the charger, without connecting the battery, I get:

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> (corresponding to the one I connected): 5V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, adjacent resistors and traces.

L3500, or LB700 must get voltage only when USB device is detected on the corresponding port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and surrounding resistors are in good condition, also with good resistance values according to the schematic.

Voltage values of the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>'s lines:

<SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_CS_L</SIGNAL>: 3.37V
<SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_MISO</SIGNAL>: 3.37V
<SIGNAL>TBT_X_ROM_WP_L</SIGNAL>: 3.37V
<SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL>: 0.4V
<SIGNAL>TBT_X_SPI_CLK</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>TBT_X_ROM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL>: 3.37V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>: 3.37V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> USB-C don't work
threads.message:
I bet for more corrosion problems in USB-C areas.
Can't be other reason, if the board works on battery.
